newsitem.title: POLAND: Pope draws big crowd, Vatican says he is well.
newsitem.headline: Pope draws big crowd, Vatican says he is well.

text.p: Pope John Paul drew a crowd of more than a million people at a mass on Sunday and his spokesman said the 77-year-old Roman Catholic leader was holding up very well and may visit Poland again.
"I refuse to accept the notion that this is the Pope's last trip to Poland," chief Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro-Valls told a news conference.

Bishop Tadeusz Pieronek, secretary of the Polish bishops' conference, also said there were "elements" that led him to believe the Pope would visit again, noting that several invitations had been made for him to come next year.
Navarro-Valls said the trip through areas of his youth was an "extraordinary" experience for the Pope.
"He is living through a lot of memories," he said, adding that the Pope was full of "intellectual curiosity" about where his country was heading.

The Pope, who has had a series of health problems in recent years, appeared in relatively good form as he presided at a three-hour-long mass for a crowd police estimated at more than 1.5 million people.
"The Pope has held up perfectly well," Navarro-Valls said, adding that he was sleeping well, although rising early as he does normally, and that "there are no signs of any particular problems."

"I'm not saying that the Pope in 1997 is the same as he was in 1978 when he was elected, but he shows he has the capacity to do the work," Navarro-Valls added, suggesting that 11 days on the road home in Poland were perhaps less fatiguing than 16-hour days mostly spent behind a desk at the Vatican.
"I think perhaps here it is less tiring," he added.

Sunday's crowd was the biggest of the trip so far. A sea of people turned out to see the Pope at the Blonia meadows in Krakow, the city where he lived for more than 20 years as priest, bishop and cardinal.
Speaking in a strong voice, the Pontiff told the pilgrims that, now they had regained freedom after nearly half a century of communism, they should use it to spread love and truth.
Thousands of banners went up in the 48-hectare field as the Pope was driven through the crowd in a glass-topped popemobile.
Wearing resplendent gold robes billowing in a soft breeze, he told the crowd that 10 years ago "we had before us the problem of the discovery of freedom".

In 1987, the country was still run by communists. Two years later in 1989 they gave way to Eastern Europe's first democratically-elected government, headed by the Solidarity trade union, which the Pope unflaggingly backed.
To the Pope's joy after years of praying for a more united Europe, the domino-like fall of the Soviet bloc was under way.
"Now divine providence is putting a new task before us: to love and serve. To love in deed and in truth," he said speaking from a flower-bedecked altar platform overlooking the expanse.

How Poles should use their freedom in the post-communist era has been the thread running through the Pope's speeches on the trip, his seventh to Poland, which ends on Tuesday when he returns to the Vatican.

Before the mass John Paul had a brief meeting with Polish Prime Minister Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz at the Krakow Archbishop's residence. Asked by Cimoszewicz in front of reporters how his trip was going, the Pope replied "fine".
The prime minister, a former communist, said later that he had told the Pope "He should be full of optimism, because we will cope with the problems that we have."
At the mass the Pope canonised Queen Jadwiga, who died in 1399 at the age of 25 after helping to spread Christianity to neighbouring countries, particularly Lithuania.

He prayed that the example of the new saint, whom Poles have venerated for centuries as a holy woman and benefactor of the arts and education, would teach the nation "what it means to love in deed and in truth, what it means to be truly free".
During the trip he has warned Poles of a moral wilderness and the pitfalls of a get-rich-quick mentality as the once-centralised economy soars to new heights.
He has pulled no punches on some of the most burning issues dividing them, most notably abortion, which he would like to see banned in his homeland.
